docs.lead_paragraph: I've been getting questions about the biochemist Bruce Ames' work, which I briefly cite in the Findings column as evidence that synthetic pesticides in our diet are a minuscule risk for cancer. So let me elaborate on the work done by him and his colleague, Lois Swirsky Gold, the director of the Carcinogenic Potency Project at Berkeley.

docs.abstract: Responses on a few issues -- outside of Iraq and immigration -- were quite striking.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last night's debate among the Republican candidates for the G.O.P. presidential nomination gave the top contenders ample time to explain some of their core beliefs. Among the more memorable moments were Senator John McCain's ardent defense of his belief in the current Iraq war strategy and impassioned defense of his support for the immigration legislation; former Mayor Rudy Giuliani's succinct responses to questions about the Iraq invasion, terrorism and his humorous comeback to the sound glitches caused by lightning from a storm; and former Gov. Mitt Romney's elaborative explanation and embrace of his Mormon faith.
docs.snippet: Responses on a few issues -- outside of Iraq and immigration -- were quite striking.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following is a transcript of the 2008 Republican presidential candidates debate hosted by CNN, WMUR-TV and The New Hampshire Union Leader. The participants were Senator Sam Brownback, the former Virginia Gov. James Gilmore, the former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani, Rep. Duncan Hunter, the former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, Sen. John McCain, Rep. Ron Paul, the former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney, Rep. Tom Tancredo, and the former Wisconsin Gov. Tommy Thompson and the moderator was Wolf Blitzer.

headline.print_headline: New Drug Extends Lives of Liver Cancer Patients, Doctors Say
headline.main: New Liver Cancer Drug Is Promising, Doctors Say

docs.lead_paragraph: The new drug could become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the deadliest forms of cancer.
docs.snippet: The new drug could become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the deadliest forms of cancer.

headline.print_headline: Two Mothers, a Camera And a Look at School Lunch
headline.main: Two Mothers, a Camera and a Look at School Lunch

headline.print_headline: Two Mothers, a Camera and a Fresh Take on School Lunches
headline.main: Two Mothers, a Camera and a Fresh Take on School Lunches

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislators must listen to the health experts and not the lobbyists for the food, drink and dairy businesses. That means banning sodas, candy, sports drinks and high-fat dairy products from schools.
docs.snippet: Legislators must listen to the health experts and not the lobbyists for the food, drink and dairy businesses. That means banning sodas, candy, sports drinks and high-fat dairy products from schools.

docs.abstract: Editorial holds there are problems with proposals by New York Gov Eliot Spitzer, Assembly Democrats and State Senate for offering more nutritious food and drink choices at schools in effort to combat obesity
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion
docs.lead_paragraph: Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up bad eating habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls ''competitive foods.'' Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt -- the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease. Lawmakers in Albany have finally started looking seriously at new guidelines for what young people eat or drink on public school property. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly Democrats and the State Senate have each come up with proposals.

docs.abstract: Editorial holds there are problems with proposals by New York Gov Eliot Spitzer, Assembly Democrats and State Senate for offering more nutritious food and drink choices at schools in effort to combat obesity
docs.section_name: Health; New York and Region; Opinion
docs.lead_paragraph: Children learn a lot at school, not all of it for the better. As the Institute of Medicine reported in April, too many children pick up very bad eating habits, habits that can eventually kill them. Part of the problem is what the institute calls ''competitive foods.'' Instead of choosing the standard lunch, students choose junk food, much of it loaded with sugar, fat and salt -- the fuel for future diabetes or heart disease. Armed with mounting data on these dangers, lawmakers in Albany have finally started looking seriously at new guidelines for what young people eat or drink on public school property. Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Assembly Democrats and the State Senate have each come up with proposals this year for better fare for students.

docs.lead_paragraph: UBELL--Earl. The Staff of PARADE Magazine mourns the loss of longtime friend and colleague, Earl Ubell, author, journalist, and PARADE Health Editor from 1982 to 1998. During his tenure at PARADE, Ubell was often ahead of the news, covering issues such as depression in children, obesity, gene testing, hormone therapy, and Parkinson's Disease, with which he was diagnosed in the late 1980s. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Shirley, his children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson, Chairman PARADE $(6$)UBELL--Earl. The Parkinson's Disease Foundation mourns the loss of a dear and gentle friend, our former Board member, Earl Ubell. His wisdom and intelligence enriched our conversations while his humor and decency warmed our hearts. We wish every comfort at this time to Shirley and their talented family. Page Morton Black, Chairman Lewis P. Rowland, M.D., President
